div.p: Greetings. Today I received your letters, honorable lord and godfather, along with two booklets concerning our Steiger and Diesbach. I have not yet offered or sent them to them due to the business that occupies both me and them; however, I will do so conveniently and shortly with your commendation. We have not yet received the remaining copies, but we expect them through a certain rosemary carrier, to whom my brother entrusted them for delivery. I am very sorry that you are not enjoying better health, so that you may continue to benefit the church and all of us with your holy labors for a longer time. Therefore, I do not cease to pray to the Lord for you, that He may preserve your full strength and prolong your days to a long age. I now understand the Paradysiacum matter better and suspect what else may be hidden under this cause; therefore, we must diligently watch and apply spurs to those who seem to care less about this matter.

I am sending back to you the news written from Antwerp; I also received those which my brother excerpted from yours and sent to me, and I thank you for all of these. I will also thank you and Mr. Simler for your booklets after we have received them.
Our Aretias is now suffering from the same illness as my wife, along with his own wife.
I greatly fear for his life; for he is a singularly learned, pious, and peace-loving man. My wife has somewhat recovered by the grace of the Lord, as have her sisters.
I am writing to my brother about our urban or civic affairs. Soldiers are still being held in prisons here and there, and nothing has yet been finally decided about them.
The Geneva matter is also still pending. Yesterday, the Savoyard envoy was here; what he actually did, I do not yet know. I therefore break off my letter, as I have nothing else now.
Farewell. Greet all yours and mine in my name. Bern, March 11, 1574.
To the most illustrious Mr. Heinrich Bullinger the Elder, my honorable lord and dearest godfather.
